docs.lead_paragraph: In 1947 President Harry S. Truman declared, ''All Americans should have the opportunity for universal good health.'' Congress defeated his health care initiative, which was denounced as ''socialism.'' In 1993 President Bill Clinton declared, ''This health care system of ours is badly broken.'' He urged Congress, within a year, to produce legislation guaranteeing health care to every citizen.

headline.main: Health Care, Where Hope Is Still a Thing With Feathers

docs.lead_paragraph: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the largest health insurer in New York State, cannot earn enough money to survive if it remains a nonprofit company. But state authorities have dawdled over its application to convert to for-profit status for nearly four years, and the Legislature threatens to exit Albany without approving Empire's request. Empire used to be the only insurer to extend coverage to all individual applicants -- those not covered through employers -- at rates that did not depend on the applicant's medical condition. But since 1996, the state has required every managed care plan to enroll individuals. Empire's special role ceased. The only way to preserve Empire's contribution to the uninsured is to approve the conversion. Empire would turn over all of its stock, worth perhaps $600 million, to an independent foundation. The foundation would later sell the stock, using the proceeds to help extend coverage to the uninsured. Empire would then issue new stock to pay for the information systems and other hugely expensive investments that are needed to match those of for-profit plans.

headline.main: Health Tasks Before the Legislature; A Transfusion for Empire

docs.lead_paragraph: They were gently spoken and kind-eyed in their white coats, but make no mistake: the handful of doctors and nurses gathering signatures outside the Massachusetts Statehouse see themselves as part of a popular health care insurgency, and some medical powers are taking them seriously enough to spend millions of dollars trying to stop them. With one final petition drive this weekend, a coalition of doctors, nurses, senior citizens' groups, labor unions and others is expected to collect the last several thousand signatures needed to place before Massachusetts voters what experts call the most sweeping health care referendum on any state's ballot this fall.

headline.main: Referendums From States Are Seeking to Overhaul the Health Care System in the U.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ask Gov. George W. Bush of Texas about the intellectual origins of his campaign's mantra and he says, ''Compassionate conservatism is first and foremost springing from the heart.'' Yet well before Mr. Bush began building his presidential campaign around the words ''compassionate conservative'' -- reshaping the image of his party to follow suit -- a cadre of thinkers on the right had been trying for years to fashion a form of conservatism that rejected the welfare state but did not turn its back on the poor. And with his campaign strategist Karl Rove acting as his guide, Mr. Bush began reading their books and meeting them, even before his first race for governor.

headline.main: Bush Draws Campaign Theme From More Than 'the Heart'

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans will flesh out their proposal for Medicare drug benefits this week and try to push it through two House committees in three days, despite fierce objections from many Democrats. Republicans said today that they would combine their drug plan with a proposal to give more money to health maintenance organizations -- perhaps $4 billion over five years -- in hope of halting the exodus of H.M.O.'s from Medicare.

headline.main: House G.O.P. to Push Its Medicare Drug Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report that ''the United States falls behind almost every country in Europe as well as Canada, Australia and Israel in what the World Health Organization calls 'healthy life expectancy' '' (news article, June 5). This should not come as a surprise. The United States does not have a national health plan, and many elderly people (and not so elderly) can barely make ends meet, let alone buy health insurance. There is no reason that the richest country in the world cannot provide medical care for all who live here.

docs.lead_paragraph: TO move from welfare to work, Tyree Dickey took a job at Southern New England Telephone and then one at St. Raphael's Hospital in New Haven, but left them both because she didn't have reliable day care for her 2-year-old son. Then with her time on welfare running out, she found a way to get job training and look after her child at the same time. ''Coming here was like 'Yes!' '' Ms. Dickey said. ''I was desperate.''

headline.main: Job Training, Child Care Under One Roof

docs.abstract: Article on All Our Kin, small pilot program in New Haven, Conn, that instructs welfare mothers in early childhood development while they care for their own children; women, after earning credentials, can then move on to jobs at day care centers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation -- the largest anywhere, with an endowment of $22 billion -- spends tens of millions of dollars each year aimed, in its own words, at ''helping to improve people's lives through health and learning.'' In addition to making a sweeping effort to vaccinate the world's children, it has backed charities like Cancer Lifeline, which provides support to people with cancer and their families, and the American Cancer Society. But according to its most recent tax return, the Gates Foundation also owned bonds in Philip Morris, the tobacco company -- raising the issue of whether the foundation's behavior as an investor sometimes runs counter to its charitable mission.

headline.main: Charities' Investing: Left Hand, Meet Right

docs.abstract: Stephen Viederman, who until recently oversaw $90 million endowment of Jessie Smith Noyes Foundation, urges charities to align their investments with their social aims; insists foundations have responsibility to consider the 'social and environment consequences of their investments'; cites Bill and Melinda Gates Foundations' investments in Philip Morris bonds, despite stated aim of 'helping to improve people's lives though health and learning'; finds most foundations, liberal or conservative, seem to believe that maximizing investment returns to fund's charitable mission is their sole responsibility and do not engage much in shareholder activism; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The problems caused by the transition to managed care are enormous, but ''New H.M.O. Fight: Medical Discipline'' (May 28) missed an important aspect of the debate. The common perception among health care consumers (formerly known as patients) is that coverage by a health maintenance organization provides all the care options needed to ensure health. In fact, it means coverage for what an employer has chosen to pay. The same insurer may deny coverage under one policy and approve it under another.
docs.abstract: Dr Terence M O'Connor, letter, responds to May 28 article on managed care; points out that HMOs merely enforce coverage decisions that are in fact made by employers and benefits managers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps because he's new at this, Jon S. Corzine arrived in New Jersey politics painting ideological markings all over himself: He's a liberal. He's a Great Society kind of guy. Grouchy Republicans are already pointing out that he is eager to spend, not just his own money but that of everybody else. So how is a state that is wild about moderation going to respond to a platform that would not be out of place in Belgium?

headline.main: A Liberal or a Moderate, It's Nice to Be Loaded

docs.abstract: Laura Mansnerus On Politics column offers her take on how what she sees as Jon Corzine's ultra liberal campaign for US Senate is playing out in usually moderate New Jersey (M)
